Please don't let the QTEs turn you off from this game. Although they are "essential" in the early parts of the game, the gameplay systems allow you to eventually ignore it with the crazy builds you can make even in early game. 

I love it when games give me the ability to have alpha strike builds that ignore turn based mechanics and with the Balatro level damage scaling in this game, it really scratches that itch.

Oh, story's also pretty good.

snippet.textDisplay:
The game is more than its combat system unlike what most people set their minds to before even playing the game to finish. The story, soundtrack, refreshing parry mechanic on a turn based game; it's all amazing to me as a long time fan of FFX. The only bad thing is how cluttered and overwhelming the UI (and combat terms) can be when you're starting out but it's great after learning all of those.

Also, the game's story pacing reminds me so much of DMC3 and I'm all here for it.
snippet.textOriginal:

The only bad thing is how cluttered and overwhelming the UI (and combat terms) can be when you're starting out but it's great after learning all of those.

Also, the game's story pacing reminds me so much of DMC3 and I'm all here for it.

snippet.textDisplay: Fighting as *Maelle* is canon for me. I had one crash in 120 hrs. That is not to say the game doesn't have problems. But we clearly had two different experiences in that regard. And I had two repeatable glitches. Neither of which are worthy of note, but I am going to note one anyway. On the rotten coast, where you originally land, if you use Moroco's Glaise Earthquakes on that map the Glaise monster will get stuck semi-permanently in the middle of the map, each one you've ever used. And they stay there until you exit the map, resting does not reset them. Doesn't break anything, but a glitch nonetheless.
snippet.textOriginal: Fighting as *Maelle* is canon for me. I had one crash in 120 hrs. That is not to say the game doesn't have problems. But we clearly had two different experiences in that regard. snippet.textDisplay:
As a long time souls and turn based enjoyer, for me, I don't necessarily like the two combining. Up to nearly the end, you're capped at 9999 anyway, so it felt kind of pointless to overly grind, maybe a few bosses I had to just to bump up my hp and def. 

I think the dodge parry being a prevalent aspect of the combat is what I didn't enjoy during my playthrough, it was fun for thr first 10 hours or so, I'm close to 50 now. It just becomes more of an annoyance having to dodge attacks that will debuff my team with exhausts, charm, or straight up taking them out of combat for a few rounds. 

I would have prefered a straight turn based affair with a more engrossing character development. As how you say Monoco felt like a forced add, that's how I felt about Sciel, she never added anything or really grew as a character, in fact the only ones that actually shown anyway real growth throughout the journey were Gustave, Verso and Maelle. Lune, Monoco and Sciel just kind of felt like they were there for the ride.

snippet.textDisplay:
Stunning, engaging, amazing. GOTY contender with no business being this good.

Would love to see a Loadout function in the game. The scarcity of re-spec potions does not at all accommodate for you to try and experiment with different builds and carry multiple weapon sets for different situations. There are a boatload of weapons in the game, and most of them scale off different stats. So even if you level up a few weapons and keep them around, chances are they will perform really poorly due to different scaling from attributes. And the Might stat in itself is pretty useless compared to Speed and Vitality.

Also, the colorblind accessibility is really poorly implemented. Still can't see shit. To the point that Luna is outright unplayable for me, since I can't see what stupid stains are active.

Great game with some rough edges. So far the timings need a sharper pass — they never feel "right," especially when the camera shifts and there are perspective swaps. This is compounded by nearly every enemy attack having multiple swings with Elden Ring-esque wind ups and delays. 

Narrative so far might be one of the greats of the genre. We'll see where it goes, but it's refreshing to have a game's story maintain a consistent tone without either popping off with quips or being too oppressive.

snippet.textDisplay:
You were so on point about the combat system.

After reaching 27 hours (about mid point of Act II), I started to feel the game becoming more and more of a slog and a chore to continue playing. While it felt fresh at first, the combat system quickly turned on its head after introducing too many ways for the enemy to "cheat" the system itself. In most encounter later in the game you either die a quick death (distracted by all the particles effects and cinematic camera angles rendering dodge and parry very difficult to read) or face a long drowned out multi-10min battle before reaching the failure point. It is not that hard, but really not enjoyable to be in situation where you have no clear agenda on the fight and just have to bring the same specific characters with the same specific builds in every fights, which remove a lot of the gameplay customization and appeal from RPG. At that point I started to play only to see through the story, which made me put down the game altogether.

All in all I am glad Gamepass exists, as this would typically be the kind of issue you don't feel within a two hours refund window.

snippet.textDisplay:
Peak fiction. This game is an absolute triumph in every sense. The visual fidelity is breathtaking, with some of the most impressive facial animations and hair physics I've ever seen. The art style is nothing short of stunning—imagine a watercolor painting that moves, full of life and depth. When it comes to turn-based combat, this is the best implementation I've encountered—strategically rich and allowing for countless character builds.

The voice acting and motion capture performances? Oscar-worthy. Every line is delivered with such authenticity and emotion. The score is equally mesmerizing—hauntingly beautiful compositions that elevate the cinematic presentation.

The writing and character development will grip you from the first scene, and the dialogue keeps you fully engaged throughout. The pacing is impeccable, both in terms of the story and gameplay. It introduces new layers of complexity and mechanics at the perfect moments, keeping things fresh long after most games have already shown you all they have to offer.

This is more than just a game—Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 represents a watershed moment in the gaming industry. It sets a new bar for what is possible, pushing boundaries in ways that will redefine the industry for generations to come.

In short, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a masterpiece. A true work of art that redefines what games can achieve.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m a bit torn. 

This game is beautiful, I love JRPGs, I love the art style, I love the themes 

BUT I sadly just don’t like the combat. It’s too rhythm/QTE based, even with all settings that try to alleviate it. 

The only other gripe I have is, while the story is an amazing premise and the themes and plot points are pretty amazing… the way the story is shown vs spoken is… disjointed. I kinda expected Gustave to REALLY be suffering at the beginning, and while they have a couple of key cutscenes showing him suffering, he is right back to normal right after the cutscene. It makes the game lose some of the weight to me.

snippet.textDisplay:
This game wasn't on my radar, but as reviews came out, it started to look interesting.  This review is the most useful so far, and it has convinced me not to buy the game, at least for now.  I'm one of those who will have a problem with the combat system.  I don't like action combat.  That timed dodge/parry system looks miserable to me, and I have no desire whatsoever to engage with it.  I was hoping that it wouldn't be necessary to engage with this system at the easiest difficulty level, but if this is not the case, then it is a show stopper for me.  If they adjust it later so that the story difficulty level really is a story difficulty level, or if they add a setting to neutralize any timing/reflex-based mechanics, then I'll take another look.

Combat is the bane of my existence.  There are so many games that have interesting stories and settings, but I simply cannot tolerate action combat mechanics that are even remotely challenging, so I have to pass on these games.  It looks like this game is yet another that I'll end up avoiding.  I appreciate games like Dragon Age: The Veilguard, which allows combat to be turned into a no-challenge affair, and South of Midnight, which has an option to skip combat and chase sequences.  I wish more story- and setting-focused games would provide options like this so that those of us who have no interest in timing/reflex-based challenges can still experience the stories and game worlds.

snippet.textDisplay:
Not gonna lie, the QTEs are a big turnoff for me, especially hearing that lategame combat is apparently balanced all around perfect inputs for the most part. Rewarding ? Sure, but i'll take statchecks and strategies any day of the week over QTEs. But that's just me though, i hope this game finds its audience, because what i've seen so far is really interesting.

Also, a pet peeve of mine, which likely won't bother anyone else, the whole "insert random french word to make it feel authentic" thing. Everybody speaks perfect english, but all of the sudden it's "Merde!" instead of "shit!". It has the exact inverse effect on me that it's supposed to have.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: All the reviews I've watched this morning give Expedition 33 high praises. It's not perfect, but what it does is far more than most AAA games in the genre. If you value your gaming hobby and you want to see a vibrant, long lasting and robust indie games sector, then buy this game and show your support. snippet.textDisplay:
The story mechanic of once per year killing everyone over a specific age seems a bit odd.  If the number goes up and down then many years nothing will happen because everyone was already killed off in a prior year and hasn't had time to grow old enough.  And if the number could go low enough then it could just kill everyone over 2 at any time, so everyone's screwed.

If they wrote the same number each year then it would always kill the oldest year of people.

I assume though the schtick is that it decreases by one each year, so each year kills two years of people... and if left unchecked it will eventually kill everyone, but is at least predictable until then.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a nitpick but, as soon as I saw children in the game the entire premise seemed too ridiculous lol. It’s already ridiculous but, it’s a video game I can buy into a crazy premise. However, if it’s a known problem that basically everyone will just be killed off, year by year, in descending order, why are people still having kids!?! That means there will come a time where the number is 10, and all the kids 9 and under have to deal with this!?! That’s not even the painter lady’s fault anymore. That’s on the adults who did that! You had a kid knowing they’d lose their parents pretty early and likely not survive to become adults. If you fail your expedition you really expect children to just keep organizing them and try to save everyone!? 

But… I’ll probably still check this out 🤣 Ok rant over 😅

snippet.textDisplay: Seems like the timing for parrying and dodging which seems vital to surviving might prove to be an accessibility issue for people with delayed reaction times. If I am getting that right they need to include an option to adjust the timing for these individuals since certain parts might be impossible for them to do because of it (my brother who has this for example could never complete the first miniboss on Sekiro because of the timing needing to parry).

snippet.textDisplay: Really mixed on this one. When the first QTE event was created it was still somehow two QTE events too many, it does nothing to contribute to gaming. On the other hand, art is great, and I am loving the vibe, and I also don't mind this type of turn based gameplay. On the third hand, it is beyond me how this is not a SteamDeck title, nothing that is half-static like turn based games shouldn't be a great fit for that, I have very little interest in using my PC to play a title of this type. We'll see, I can wait for those SteamDeck updates.
